content.raw:
Forgot to mention: 

* I decoupled the image name from the directory it is stored in. The image name is now always either vrx or vrx\_nvidia depending on which was built. 
* I removed the requirement that the Dockerfile be stored in the same directory as the build script. I’m not sure why we were requiring this, so please let me know if I should put it back.
content.html:
Forgot to mention:

  • I decoupled the image name from the directory it is stored in. The image name is now always either vrx or vrx_nvidia depending on which was built.
  • I removed the requirement that the Dockerfile be stored in the same directory as the build script. I’m not sure why we were requiring this, so please let me know if I should put it back.

content.raw: Sure. Is there a simple way to just say “use mine”?
content.html: Sure. Is there a simple way to just say “use mine”?

content.raw: I use `meld` to resolve the conflicts if that helps.
content.html: I use meld to resolve the conflicts if that helps.

content.raw: Thanks! I was just asking because there’s nothing to merge! I just want the file to stay dead… surprised there’s not a button or something. Anyway, I think it’s fixed now. :slight_smile:
content.html: Thanks! I was just asking because there’s nothing to merge! I just want the file to stay dead… surprised there’s not a button or something. Anyway, I think it’s fixed now.

content.raw:
‌

I could only test the non-nvidia version here at home.  I had issues with the DIST and GAZ variables in the Dockerfile.  I think [21633c7](#!/osrf/vrx/commits/21633c7522499e749ce86edf49eadb74ba987ac0) fixes the issue by setting as persistent ENV variables within the Dockerfile.

Please take a look at the [Docker build tutorial](#!/osrf/vrx/wiki/tutorials/buildRunLocalImage) to make sure I captured both the nvidia and non-nvidia options correctly.
content.html:
‌

I could only test the non-nvidia version here at home. I had issues with the DIST and GAZ variables in the Dockerfile. I think 21633c7 fixes the issue by setting as persistent ENV variables within the Dockerfile.

Please take a look at the Docker build tutorial to make sure I captured both the nvidia and non-nvidia options correctly.

content.raw:
Brian,

Thanks for looking at this. You should be able to build both nvidia and non-nvidia images on any machine.

I’m glad you caught that mistake. Since we’re using the variables at build-time I think it’s better to use ARG than ENV. I changed this in 0685531.

Also, I think we no longer need the docker/vrx directory, so I’m removing it. This makes it less likely that users will confuse the directory name with the image names when following the tutorial.

Your summary of the current state of the build and run scripts in the tutorial is correct, but it will be out of date once the changes above are committed. I will update it.

Another note about the tutorial: I think the instructions would be much simpler if we just have the user clone the repository. A little more data has to be pulled, but fewer commands are needed. What do you think?

Finally, I noticed that the command 

`apt-key adv --keyserver hkp://ha.pool.sks-keyservers.net:80 --recv-key 421C365BD9FF1F717815A3895523BAEEB01FA116`

sometimes fails with a “keyserver receive failed” error. Then, later, it works fine. This causes the Dockerfile to die on step 7. I will add a note to the tutorial that says “if this happens, wait and try again.” If you have a better solution though please let me know.

Michael
content.html:
Brian,

Thanks for looking at this. You should be able to build both nvidia and non-nvidia images on any machine.

I’m glad you caught that mistake. Since we’re using the variables at build-time I think it’s better to use ARG than ENV. I changed this in 0685531.

Also, I think we no longer need the docker/vrx directory, so I’m removing it. This makes it less likely that users will confuse the directory name with the image names when following the tutorial.

Your summary of the current state of the build and run scripts in the tutorial is correct, but it will be out of date once the changes above are committed. I will update it.

Another note about the tutorial: I think the instructions would be much simpler if we just have the user clone the repository. A little more data has to be pulled, but fewer commands are needed. What do you think?

Finally, I noticed that the command

apt-key adv --keyserver hkp://ha.pool.sks-keyservers.net:80 --recv-key 421C365BD9FF1F717815A3895523BAEEB01FA116

sometimes fails with a “keyserver receive failed” error. Then, later, it works fine. This causes the Dockerfile to die on step 7. I will add a note to the tutorial that says “if this happens, wait and try again.” If you have a better solution though please let me know.

Michael

content.raw:
Roger all.  

Yes, after doing some reading ARG is much better.  Still on the very start of the Docker learning curve.

I’ve experienced the same behavior with the keyserver.  I think @caguero has a work around, but having a note in the tutorial is a good stopgap.
content.html:
Roger all.

Yes, after doing some reading ARG is much better. Still on the very start of the Docker learning curve.

I’ve experienced the same behavior with the keyserver. I think @caguero has a work around, but having a note in the tutorial is a good stopgap.
